title.narrative: Biodiversity Conservation and Rural Livelihoods Improvement

description.narrative: To develop and promote new models of conservation at the landscape scale1 through enhanced capacity and institution building for mainstreaming biodiversity conservation outcomes.Achieving this objective would involve the demonstration and scaling up of landscape conservation approaches. This would specifically involve tools and techniques improvements, and knowledge and capacity building tosupport multi-stakeholder partnerships to mainstream biodiversity conservation. It would also involve improving rural livelihoods, enhancing learning, and replicating successful participatory conservation models at the landscape scale.

title.narrative: Adoption of landscape management approaches or specific elements of it in three additional sites with GOI funding

target.value: Landscape conservation funded by GOI in 3 or more additional landscape

actual.value: In 3 landscapes from State Government budget

title.narrative: At least 75% of targeted villages or user groups completed and successfully implementing micro-plans with conservation benefits

target.value: 20% increase in incomes for VPs/user groups where microplans are prepared in Year 1-3

actual.value: Income increases reported for limited beneficiaries but not measured

title.narrative: Design of landscape sites for Component 3

actual.value: This indicator was achieved as landscape activities were initiated but with a delay of over 1 year

title.narrative: At least 20% of target user groups adopt alternate and/or sustainable resource use practices
Key stakeholders from at least five national priority landscapes trained in landscape conservation approaches
Adoption of landscape management approaches in two additional sites with project funding
At least two protected areas covering 550,000 hectares with strengthened management and protection (40% increase in management effectiveness)
Landscape conservation approach successfully adopted in two landscape sites
Effective and well-staffed national coordination unit within MOEF actively supporting landscape approaches
National curriculum for landscape conservation developed and training institutionalized through five new annual training courses
At least 50,000 ha of targeted production areas outside PAs managed for conservation outcomes
At least 600,000 hectares within landscapes more effectively managed for conservation outcomes
At least 10 new documents on good practice prepared and knowledge dissemination events sponsored

baseline.value: A number of good practice notes from previous projects exist

title.narrative: Institutional and methodological framework and guidelines for landscape conservation approaches developed and tested in high biodiversity landscapes

target.value: Formal approval of guidelines and procedures by MOEF based on field testing

title.narrative: On time completion of key project outputs against implementation plan

target.value: Bi-annual progress reports, annual work plans approved in time, quarterly FMRs and annual audit reports submitted, procurementplans updated

actual.value: Consolidated bi annual progress reports not submitted; updated procurement plans not shared and uploaded on to STEP platform; IUFRsubmission is generally delayed

title.narrative: New areas outside protected areas managed as biodiversity-friendly (ha)
Areas brought under enhanced biodiversity protection (ha)
Governmentt institutions provided with capacity building to improve management of forest resources
Forest area brought under management plans
At least 20% of targeted populations in landscapes have improved cash or non-cash improved incomes from project-supported interventions

baseline.value: Current baselines vary depending on source of income and dependency [e.g., salt mining, Rs 40,000- 50,000 /HH/year; fishing andgrazing (supplement incomes) and much higher for wild plant trade

target.value: 10% increase in incomes for VPs/user groups where micro-plans prepared in Year 1

actual.value: Income increases not measured and cannot be varified

title.narrative: Population of key indicator species/umbrella species stable or improving within PAs

baseline.value: No regular surveys of key indicator species, except Wild Ass (3,863 in 2004)

target.value: Regular monitoring to assess population status

actual.value: Regular monitoring of key indicator species undertaken across all landscape sites; Wild Ass estimated at 4451 in 2014 census
